title: About
text:
obertwwalker.github.io 




Robert W. Walker, Ph. D.





Robert W. Walker is an Associate Professor of Quantitative Methods in the Atkinson Graduate School of Management at Willamette University
He earned a Ph. D. in political science from the University of Rochester in 2005 and has previously held teaching positions at Dartmouth College, Rice University, Texas A&M University, and Washington University in Saint Louis. His current research develops and applies semi-Markov processes to time-series, cross-section data in international relations and international/comparative political economy. He teaches courses in quantitative methods/applied statistics and microeconomic strategy and previously taught four iterations in the U. S. National Science Foundation funded Empirical Implications of Theoretical Models sequence at Washington University in Saint Louis. His work with Curt Signorino and Muhammet Bas was awarded the Miller Prize for the best article in Political Analysis in 2009.
His web presence is rww.science and his github is https://github.com/robertwwalker.


Robert’s Erdos-Bacon Number is 8.





Erdos Table







Bacon Table

title: A Syllabus and Models
text:
What is a model?
Our reading for next time defines models in science. This is a hard read but it is the only reading for the week.
Models in Science from the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
We will pay extra attention to sections 1, 3, and 5.2.
The class plan:

Discuss the syllabus, deliverables, and requirements
An overview of the course and mutual introductions.
A brief discussion of models to set the foundations for Thursday.

Your assignment for next time:

Do the reading.
Collect at least three questions and the answers provided by Google Gemini about references in the reading that were unfamiliar. If you did not run across at least three unfamiliar references, you need a more advanced course.

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text: Welcome to Managing with Data, Analytics, and Artificial Intelligence!

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
1. Models

Our organizing framework is the model. What is a model? Why models?

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
2. Data

What is data and how do we get some? We start by defining data and our relationship with data. We will explore practical methods of data gathering – from surveys and archives to experiments and crowd sourcing.
Have data, how is it typically organized? We will explore basic methods of organizing data for robust, sustainable use.

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
3. Deploying Data

How can managers use data? We will deploy basic tools of cross tabulation, frequency distributions, and simple plots before some statistical inference and model building.

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
4. Artificial Intelligence

What is artificial intelligence (AI)? We will highlight general features of how commonly deployed AI systems function and how they can solve challenges across various areas of business.
